results.title: Dorothy Heathcote talks to teachers. Pt. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernice Gregorio, Dana H. Hodgdon and Northwestern University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
Drama in the classroom continues with the discussion of techniques developed by Mrs. Heathcote. “Questioning”, “storyline”, “universals” and “brother hoods” are examined. Drama is related to developing language and social skills, while teaching subject material. Mrs. Heathcote’s educative process is based on total involvement that ultimately modifies behaviour.

results.title: Dorothy Heathcote talks to teachers. Pt. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernice Gregorio, Dana H. Hodgdon and Northwestern University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
In a teachers’ workshop, Dorothy Heathcote, England’s outstanding drama educator, explores the theory of improvised drama as a teaching tool for all classroom teachers. She analyses her unique process, explaining and illustrating techniques for developing materials, the use of dramatic elements and the segmenting of ideas to achieve dramatic focus.

results.title: Dorothea [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Wendy Chandler, Anna Grieve and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A young Greek woman, Dorothea, escapes her family’s resistance to adopting new ways and an arranged marriage by becoming involved in a theatre group and falling for the lead performer. Cast includes Helen Dullas, William Dye and Saavas Panas.

results.title: Doris Lessing
results.creator_credit: John Archer and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Well known writer Doris Lessing is interviewed about her life in Africa and the books she has written including “The grass is singing”, “The golden notebook”, “Briefing for a descent into hell”, and “Marriage between Zones 3,4 and 5”.

results.title: Doppler effect
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Explains the factors which determine the pitch of a sound. Waves are shown advancing toward the listener, and the following cases are treated: 1. Source and listener stationary; 2. Source in motion, listener stationary (accompanying change of wave-length and consequent change of apparent frequency are described in slow motion); 3. Source stationary, listener in motion (shows that no change in wave-length occurs, but that there is a change of apparent frequency).

results.title: Donkeys
results.brief_description: Shows the physical and behavioural characteristics of adult and young donkeys which are closely observed in this non-narrated film. Also features close-up studies of individual details, with a soundtrack of music and natural sounds. Suitable for primary school level.

results.creator_credit: Don Bennetts, AFFC and Art Gallery of New South Wales

results.title: Donald and the wheel
results.creator_credit: Hamilton Luske and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck accidently invents the wheel. Later Egyptians, Greek, Romans and others improve on it. Through songs and commentary the possible history of the wheel is traced. Donald, however, is not very impressed, particularly the aspect of the chaos of modern traffic.
results.description: Donald Duck accidently invents the wheel. Later Egyptians, Greek, Romans and others improve on it. Through songs and commentary the possible history of the wheel is traced. Donald, however, is not very impressed, particularly the aspect of the chaos of modern traffic.

results.title: Don Quixote
results.brief_description: Outlandishly loopy cartoon from this pioneering american animator. Quixote’s world is transfigured by his own unchecked imagination - he navigates an enchanted vista of fairy-tale cliches. Whimsical questing for gallant ideals ends in fevered retreat to the sanctuary of Ye Olde Bughouse. Disarmingly innocent and frenetically paced, this is among Iwerk’s best works.
